instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Won't boot up unless SMC reset is performed
threads.message:
Have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that originally came in for power failure. Found corrosion damage around <RESISTOR>R5420</RESISTOR>. Had to repair wire traces from pin 3 and 4 to pin 5 and 4 on <CHIP>U5420</CHIP>. The board worked at the point. But got returned a few months after with a new issue. Now the board requires smc reset before it will boot up. I would have to let is remained powered off for about an hour to be able to recreate the no power issue, at which point, i have to reperform smc reset to be able to power it again. 

I installed the board in another frame to confirm it wasn't the battery and i also replace the SMC with the same result. 

I can't recreate the issue unless the battery is connected. Once the board is out of the frame, it comes on all the time. 

Any suggestion on where to start?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Won't boot up unless SMC reset is performed
threads.message:
Test if starts in SMC bypass in that moment.
Check R/<CAPACITOR>C5426</CAPACITOR>.

Also check for corrosion around <CHIP>U8510</CHIP>.
Be sure <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> are steady high.

Inspect J6100 for corrosion too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Won't boot up unless SMC reset is performed
threads.message:
There is no <RESISTOR>R5426</RESISTOR> or <CAPACITOR>C5426</CAPACITOR> on the board. But to perform the SMC bypass, doesn't it require the battery to be unplugged? The board boots up without issue all the time when the battery is unplugged. 

And yes <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> are steady high at 3.41v during the time when the unit won't boot. They both go to zero when I perform the smc reset as expected. 

No corrosion on J6100 and pulled <CHIP>U8510</CHIP>, no corrosion. Went ahead and replaced <CHIP>U8510</CHIP> just in case. Same result. 

One thing i did notice, not sure if this is something to be concerned about, but every line that runs off <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> has a diode mode reading of 0.381 compared to two know good boards reading of 0.469.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Won't boot up unless SMC reset is performed
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST</SIGNAL> level at that moment.
Also disconnect keyboard and test if board start with SW9988/89 at same moment.

You cannot expect the exact same reading on different boards; even when are the same model.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Won't boot up unless SMC reset is performed
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST</SIGNAL> is 0v both before and after smc reset.

SW9988/89 don't work, its a floating connection. These version board are missing <RESISTOR>R9988</RESISTOR>/<CAPACITOR>C9988</CAPACITOR>. Confirmed on two other boards.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Won't boot up unless SMC reset is performed
threads.message:
"SW9988/89 don't work, its a floating connection."
I don't exactly understand what you mean.
Just need to use one of them instead of power button.

<CAPACITOR>C9988</CAPACITOR> is marked as "NO STUFF", but is very strange to miss <RESISTOR>R9988</RESISTOR>.
However, just trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground in this case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Won't boot up unless SMC reset is performed
threads.message: I can confirm that SW9988/89 is a floating connection, with missing <RESISTOR>R9988</RESISTOR> on the two <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boards I have looked at.
